samples.context: In a small town, there was a student who understood that if they studied hard, they would get good grades. Also, if they participated in extracurricular activities, they would make new friends. The student either studied hard or participated in extracurricular activities. If someone makes new friends, they will get invited to social events.
samples.question: Given that Alex did not get good grades, does Alex get invited to social events?

samples.context: At a robotics competition, a team hoped to win top prize. They knew that if their design was innovative, they would impress the judges. Also, if their robot was highly functional, they would score well. But someone either has an innovative design or functional robot. If a team scores highly, they will win top prize.
samples.question: Given that the judges were not impressed, did the team win top prize?

samples.context: At a science fair, a student was presenting their project. They understood that if their display looks nice, judges will be impressed. Also, if their research is thorough, experts will take them seriously. But someone will either have a good display or thorough research. If experts take a project seriously, it will receive an award.
samples.question: Given that the judges were not impressed with the display, did the project receive an award?

samples.context: In a restaurant kitchen, a chef knew that if they carefully follow a recipe, the dish will turn out well, and if they use high-quality ingredients, the food will taste delicious. But the chef either follows the recipe closely or uses excellent ingredients. If something tastes great, it will become a popular menu item.
samples.question: Given that the chef did not follow the recipe closely, did the dish become popular on the menu?

samples.context: At a busy restaurant, a new chef knew that if they followed recipes precisely, their dishes would come out well.
